do not meet the minimum conditions for having any moral standing at all

CHAPTER 19 ■Moral Reasoning
because they lack interests. Steinbock (1992, p. 5) has presented this argu-
ment clearly:
Beings that have moral status must be capable of caring about what is done to
them. They must be capable of being made, if only in a rudimentary sense,
happy or miserable, comfortable or distressed. Whatever reasons we may have
for preserving or protecting non-sentient bei
